/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The above sentence adds absolutely no value beyond the shortlog ie. first line.

Also "the" OOM issue means you are referring to one specific issue.

Something like this which is culled from the linux documentation is actually useful to the reader:

min_free_kbytes:

This is used to force the Linux VM to keep a minimum number
of kilobytes free.  The VM uses this number to compute a
watermark[WMARK_MIN] value for each lowmem zone in the system.
Each lowmem zone gets a number of reserved free pages based
proportionally on its size.

Keeping more memory free in those zones means that the operating system itself is less likely to run out of memory during high memory pressure and high allocation events.
Typo, should be "shows" instead of "shown"
For future reference, should be cherry-picked from next most recent stable branch after it has merged there so tracking stays intact.

Sean is correct, but it looks like the extra cherry-pick info was missed in the v->u backport, so there's probably no sense updating it here.  At least we have the Change-Id connecting all the backports.  But in the future, please do the picks from n->n-1, n-1->n-2, etc.

I have changed bios.py to remove the instance check on AttributeRegistry as the identity check is sufficient. I've also removed the "message registry" strings to make it a generic registry.
Does it mean that the same Redfish API cannot have both message and attribute registries?
A registry collection can and does have both message and attributes registries. However a particular registry can be either message or attribute.

sushy/resources/registry/attribute_regis.message: It's not a free-form field, it has a defined structure. Changing it later will be breaking, so we should probably add the structure right way.

Good point. I updated this to set common attribute fields based on https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/AttributeRegistry.v1_3_4.json and on what multiple vendors are reporting. I'll also update the spec to list these fields.

sushy/resources/registry/message_registr.message:
need to update param name to 'registries' and associated docstring as that can include attribute registries now.

Alternatively, could ask that this already contains filtered registries and remove changes in ln102-104, but that would lead to repetitive code every time `parse_message` is called if there is no handy property available (like registries.message_registries :))
could update a test case for message parsing where unrelated registries are present to check that test still passes.
Renaming parameters is a breaking change, doesn't seem justified here.
This is a breaking change, do we really need to do it? Maybe provide a compatibility alias?
Thanks for the review! I've changed this to reinstate the public API and also added a function to get the attribute registry.

+1, in relation to my other comment, maybe need to rethink how these registries are organized (and try to keep existing public API if possible), and have distinction between message, attribute and other future registries.
instead of passing registry type, could pass module and class name for instance to create and avoid repeating the same code.
Good point. Added and removed duplicate logs.

sushy/resources/system/bios.py.message:
if some filtering on _registries is necessary here, does it mean that also when only Message registries are necessary, that filtering needs to be done too to at least avoid iterating unrelated files? E.g., for parsing messages [1]

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/branch/master/sushy/resources/registry/message_registry.py#L89
Good point. For parse_messages though, its also used for the Task class in addition to MessageRegistry. I've added a check that the class has the messages attribute, which is necessary.

openstackclient/volume/client.py.message: Probably good for a follow-up, but what about specifying later versions, too? We shouldn't fail if a user wants 3.43 or later?

Tbh I'm not sure what's the best approach here, as probably we also need to implement changes in client somewhere if we want to support more modern functionality. Ideally all api versions should be mentioned here, but then the list would be enormous. So I'd rather leave that for the follow up and professionals:)

I think defaulting to the base 3.0 version is the safest. At least with the cinder client, the behavior is to do this for making calls unless the user explicitly asks for a more recent microversion. That protects against behavior subtly changing between identical calls if the provider happens to do an upgrade in between.

Not related to this patch, but cinder dropped the v1 API several releases ago now. I know we want to continue to support older deployments for as long as we can in osc, but it might be worth thinking about cleaning up some of this as cinder is now trying to drop v2 and get to the point where only v3 is supported.

member_count = session.query(models.Member).filter(models.Member.pool_id = pool_id, models.Member.provisioning_status != consts.DELETED).count()

It's the text I'm asking about. IIRC for minor upgrade migration is recommended as the node needs to be rebooted but it's not mandatory.

The issue is when you have instances on a compute node and restart virtlogd, the console.log files get closed and not re-opened again. As a result you need to either migrate off the instances and restart virtlogd, or when virtlogd got restarted, also restart the instances or migrate them to another host to get the console.log open again. or you mean we could just remove 'without migration off instances.' from the text?
Ack, maybe could be made clearer if this is added to update docs
It is for manual restart and for updates where no reboot is done or maybe deferred to some later maintenance window depending on the size of the env.

we spoke about this at the ptg and decied that we should normalise all responce codes for unsupported operations to be a 400 going forward and we are going to retroactivly backport the chagne to existing apis.


(gmann): Consistent return code for "Feature not implemented'

    There is in consistency on what return code we should return for  "Feature not implemented'. Currently we return 400, 409, and 403.

    400 case: Example: Multiattach Swap Volume Not Supported:

    https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0c64f4c3eae8e2654ec11f60682c0fa5eda30c1a/nova/exception.py#L295

    https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/788035add9b32fa841389d906a0e307c231456ba/nova/api/openstack/compute/volumes.py#L429

    403 case: Cyborg integration.

    https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0c64f4c3eae8e2654ec11f60682c0fa5eda30c1a/nova/exception.py#L158

    https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0e7cd9d1a95a30455e3c91916ece590454235e0e/nova/api/openstack/compute/suspend_server.py#L47

    409 case: Example: Operation Not Supported For SEV , Operation Not Supported For VTPM

    https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0c64f4c3eae8e2654ec11f60682c0fa5eda30c1a/nova/exception.py#L528-L537

    Discussion started in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/780333/5//COMMIT_MSG#11

    API SIG guidlines suggest to use 400 : https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/http/response-codes.html#use-of-501-not-implemented

    If we modify the existing return code of  "Feature not implemented' to 400 then we do not need microversion bump as 400 is existing return code for any API. 

    https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/microversions.html#id3

    (sean-k-mooney)i was ok with 403 as a client is not allowed to automaticaly retry the same request unmodified if they recive a 403. the same would be true of a 400, a 409 allows the request to be retired.

    for that an other reasons since the user cant "fix" the request to make it succeed i don't like useing 409 for this but i would be ok with a 400 in all existing cases

    HTTP 501? https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/501

    https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/http/response-codes.html#use-of-501-not-implemented

    Ah, it's the HTTP *method* that's not implemented

    400 = "your bad request", 500 = "my bad, server has screwed up"+1

    some operators have sla where 5XX errors are considerd a breakage of the sla and is billable

    damn, ninja'd it's the literally obvious choice :P

    its explictly against the recommend useage of 501

    they are not  server failure and that refers to http methods not logical operation 

    AGREED:

    use 400, no need microversion to update the APIs to it

    backport it

tripleoclient/utils.py.message: is "stage" not in "UpgradePrepare" meant to filter out all non-upgrade scenarios?

Yes, as per [1] the "UpgradePrepare" is that steps which is supposed to consolidate the heat templates and they are processed when that command is run.
By adding this if statement we can make sure that this check is run only when:

1. RGW is passed to the env files
2. we're running the upgrade prepare command

If these conditions are met, we should check the Swift resource value and raise the exception if we're passing an invalid config.

Atm I've just considered the FFU context (UpgradePrepare is the class which is able to call this check), I'm not sure we need to extend this check for minor updates as well (UpdatePrepare) [2] 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/stable/train/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_update.py#L87

[2] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/stable/train/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_update.py#L87

maybe having something like:

```
stage_pattern = re.compile("(Upgrade|Update)Prepare", re.I)
if not re.match(stage_pattern, stage) or rgw_env == 'OS::Heat::None':
    return
```
helps extending the coverage to minor updates.

tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_deploy.py.message:
Lukas, the goal is to block upgrade and ffu from happening if the new env has RGW while the existing stack has Swift

can you help review to see if this works well for you?

Just a little more context: as per [1], for fresh deployments, when -e cephadm.yaml is added in the tht env list, RGW is deployed by default (with ceph-ansible we needed to explicitly include ceph-rgw.yaml).
This is really easy for fresh deployments, but for pre-existing clusters where swift was deployed we need to avoid (in an upgrade context) that swift is automatically replaced by rgw when cephadm.yaml is included.
The check provided by this review compares the resources of the existing stack and the env passed by the operator, raising an exception if swift exists and rgw is passed.
In any case, during an update/upgrade, moving from swift to rgw is something we won't support, hence we're identifying the caller (the class which calls the take_action method) to filter the update/upgrade use case and check if the config is valid or not.


[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/786827/

Typically I would say that glean-early.service should be a requires not a wants. But I guess if glean-early fails we want the udev units to do their absolute best to configure something that is workable so that things can be debugged.

That may be worth a comment? A followup change is fine.

Yeah, I think I just defaulted to "wants" because in the man page it says "This is the recommended way to hook start-up of one unit to the start-up of another unit." 

As you say, if this is a requires then glean-early failure would kill this; while I don't expect glean-early to fail, if it did, I don't think that indicates this setup of the network should not try to run.
